page.title: 04CUSTOMS-WROTH SILVER
page.content: Along the A45/M45 junction, Thurlaston there is a line of Scots Pines.The original three miles were planted by the Duke of Montagu, 1740.He also planted four pine trees near the Wroth Silver mound(supposedly the grave of Colbrand the Danish giant slain by Guy of Warwick AD920).On the mound lies a stone with a square hole, once the base of a cross. At dawn on November 11th, the Lord of the Manor and those paying dues would gather around.The steward would ask the parishes in turn to place their money in the stone walking around it three times.Failure to pay meant loss of money or a white bull with red nose and ears.The custom still continues today. P.S. In medieval times when a new house was built,a dead cat was placed in the thatched roof to frighten away evil spirits and witches.
